conclusion: To determine the ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration for particles A and B during their deceleration phases, we need to analyze the velocity-time graphs for both particles.
Particle A starts from rest and accelerates to a velocity of 2v0 in the first t0 seconds.
Particle B starts from rest and accelerates to a velocity of v0 in the first t0 seconds.
Both particles then decelerate to rest in the next 4t0 seconds.
Particle A: v = 2v0 at t = t0
Particle A: v = 2v0 at t = 2t0
Particle A: v = 2v0 at t = 3t0
Particle A: v = 2v0 at t = 4t0
Particle A: v = 0 at t = 5t0
Particle B: v = v0 at t = t0
Particle B: v = v0 at t = 2t0
Particle B: v = v0 at t = 3t0
Particle B: v = 0 at t = 4t0
Particle B: v = 0 at t = 5t0
Particle A: Acceleration during the first t0 seconds: a_A = (v - 2v0)/t0 = (v - 2v0)/t0
Particle A: Acceleration during the next 3t0 seconds: a_A = (0 - 2v0)/(3t0) = -2v0/(3t0)
Particle A: Acceleration during the next 4t0 seconds: a_A = (0 - 2v0)/(4t0) = -v0/(2t0)
Particle B: Acceleration during the first t0 seconds: a_B = (v0 - 0)/t0 = v0/t0
Particle B: Acceleration during the next 3t0 seconds: a_B = (0 - v0)/(3t0) = -v0/(3t0)
Particle B: Acceleration during the next 4t0 seconds: a_B = (0 - v0)/(4t0) = -v0/(4t0)
